docs.title: Complete Aircraft Design (AE 4311)
docs.text: Course: AE 4311 – Aircraft Design Term: Fall 2025 Project Type: Semester-long team design Aircraft: Six-passenger single-engine turboprop (low-wing, T-tail)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Designed a complete preliminary aircraft configuration starting from mission requirements and progressing through configuration selection, sizing, performance analysis, weight and balance, and stability evaluation. The design emphasizes realistic constraints, feasibility, and comparison to existing turboprop aircraft.

docs.title: Final Aircraft Summary
docs.text:
• Passengers: 6 + 1 pilot
  • Maximum Takeoff Weight: ~9,700 lb
  • Cruise Speed: 180 kt at 20,000 ft
  • Design Range: 1,750 nmi + 45-min reserve
  • Wing Area: 346.4 ft²
  • Wing Loading: ~28 lb/ft²
  • Power Loading: ~0.078 hp/lbf
  • Configuration: Low-wing, single-engine turboprop, T-tail
  • Fuselage Length: 36 ft

docs.title: My Contributions
docs.text:
• Aircraft sizing using constraint analysis
  • Performance estimation (takeoff, climb, cruise, stall, range)
  • Component-level weight estimation
  • CG excursion and static margin analysis
  • Support on configuration trade studies and final documentation

docs.title: Key Analyses
docs.text:
• Constraint sizing used to select wing and power loading
  • Weight breakdown and CG excursion across loading cases
  • Neutral point estimation using tail volume and lift-curve slopes
  • Verified positive static margin across all loading conditions

docs.title: Results
docs.text:
• Mission and performance requirements satisfied
  • CG envelope remains forward of the neutral point for all cases
  • Configuration balances aerodynamic efficiency, stability, and practicality
  • Weight class and configuration are consistent with comparable GA turboprop programs

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
• MATLAB
  • Spreadsheet-based trade studies
  • Aircraft comparison and engineering references
  • LaTeX (final report)

docs.title: Links
docs.text: • Final Design Report (PDF): Available upon request

docs.title: Afterburning Turbofan Engine Design & Optimization
docs.text: Course: AE 4451 – Jet & Rocket Propulsion Term: Fall 2025 Project Type: Team-based engine cycle design and optimization Engine Type: Afterburning turbofan with combined nozzle

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Developed a full thermodynamic cycle model for an air-breathing turbine engine and optimized its performance across two flight regimes: static ground roll and high-altitude subsonic cruise. The final configuration balances thrust capability, fuel efficiency, and operational flexibility using a unified engine architecture.

docs.title: Engine Configuration
docs.text:
• Architecture: Afterburning turbofan, combined exhaust nozzle
  • Compressor pressure ratio: ≈ 40
  • Fan pressure ratio: ≈ 1.3
  • Bypass ratio: ≈ 5.0
  • Bleed air modeled: Yes
  • Afterburner modeled: Yes

This single hardware configuration satisfies both takeoff and cruise requirements using only throttle-level adjustments.

docs.title: My Contributions
docs.text:
• Developed component-level thermodynamic cycle equations
  • Implemented full engine model in MATLAB
  • Modeled diffuser, fan, compressor, combustor, turbines, mixer, and nozzle
  • Validated model against provided test cases (<5% error)
  • Performed genetic-algorithm optimization for efficiency and thrust

docs.title: Key Analyses
docs.text:
• Cycle modeling of turbofan, turbojet, and ramjet configurations
  • Combined-nozzle performance modeling and comparison
  • Genetic-algorithm optimization of:
  • Compressor and fan pressure ratios
  • Bypass ratio
  • Fuel-to-air and afterburner fuel ratios
  • Bleed fraction
  • Separate optimization for:
  • Maximum efficiency
  • Maximum thrust

docs.title: Maximum Efficiency Configuration
docs.text:
• Specific thrust (ground roll): ~2.77 kN·s/kg
  • Specific thrust (cruise): ~2.25 kN·s/kg
  • TSFC (ground roll): ~0.009 kg/kN·s
  • TSFC (cruise): ~0.020 kg/kN·s

docs.title: Maximum Thrust Configuration
docs.text:
• Specific thrust (ground roll): ~6.25 kN·s/kg
  • Specific thrust (cruise): ~4.41 kN·s/kg
  • Demonstrates substantial thrust margin beyond mission requirements

docs.title: Results
docs.text:
• Single engine configuration meets thrust requirements at both flight regimes
  • Optimization favored high compressor ratio and moderate bypass ratio
  • Combined nozzle selected for improved accuracy and compactness
  • Engine demonstrates strong efficiency–thrust trade capability
  • Design reflects realistic characteristics of modern turbofan engines :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
• MATLAB (cycle modeling, optimization, genetic algorithms)
  • Thermodynamic property tables
  • Analytical propulsion equations
  • LaTeX (final report)
